comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Had fun working this one out - Glebe Island Bridge (1903+) in the background,  Johnstone's Bay in the middle, from Balmain looking south.

Wonder what and when that floating dry dock was?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It was called the Jubilee Dock, built 1887 (Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee). Fascinating!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It's almost impossible to visualize this bay from GoogleMaps and satellite view as there has been so much land reclamation in the area. It is easier to see on this 1907 interactive map - the bay is just to the south of "BALMAIN Terminus" in red ink - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-db66-sd&rgn=0....

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks Beachcomber, this one would have been a challenge :) There is still a 'Jubilee Street' in that area, (just had a squix on Google maps). Thank you for the link to the NLA map - it is so amazing just how much the landscape in that area has changed!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: Johnstone's Bay looked much more rural when George Halstead painted it c1870: from State Library: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=456536 and in a photo c1870 also from State Library: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=413663 The house in photo, (slnsw 413663) at top left with the garret windows, is 'Hampton Villa' built c1847 by Edward Hunt MLC.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] Great finds,  well done you!  I wondered where Hampton Villa was/is,  because Henry Parkes lived there 1888-92.  

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4753616932/]

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content:
Thanks [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  Hampton Villa still exists in Grafton Street, Balmain, and is listed in the NSW Estate Register.
 Edward Hunt MLC was my g-g-g-g-g-uncle. He died in 1866 and the family and in-laws  retained the house up to and including the time Henry Parkes occupied it as a tenant from 1888 to 1892. He was Premier up to 1891. He severely injured his leg in  a riding fall in 1889 and could not travel, hence a number of  NSW Government Cabinet meetings were held at Hampton Villa . The family had the onerous, and somewhat unpopular duty,  of evicting him for significant unpaid rent in 1892. Parkes moved to Annandale and continued his push for Federation but sadly died a pauper in 1895.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Interesting find AndyBrii (& interesting family history...) Thanks for the extra images of the site, it looks so beautiful in the painting! And a small lonely jetty in the foreground, an indicator what was to come..?
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Jubilee Floating Dry Dock is shown in this location on the wonderful 1905 birds-eye interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-f115-sd&rgn=0.... (found when looking for something else)

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Great map, I never would have spotted the dock there :)
